markdown.headingText: ! This kind of input is not handled.
markdown.markdown:
2/6/2026
Question 4: What problems do you encounter when working with the dataset?
Answer:
1) when I paste the code inside of the assignment document I received this error.
Error in `haven::read_dta()`:
! This kind of input is not handled.
Run `rlang::last_trace()` to see where the error occurred.
> rlang::last_trace()
<error/rlang_error>
Error in `haven::read_dta()`:
Backtrace:
    ▆
 1. └─haven::read_dta("https://github.com/datageneration/home/blob/master/DataProgra\nmming/data/TEDS_2016.dta?raw=true")
Run rlang::last_trace(drop = FALSE) to see 2 hidden frames.

while Chat GPT said I should write read_stat instead of read_data.
2) I paste this from the book:
> # Prepare the analyze the Party ID variable 
> # Assign label to the values (1=KMT, 2=DPP, 3=NP, 4=PFP, 5=TSU, 6=NPP, 7="NA")
> 
> TEDS_2016$PartyID <- factor(TEDS_2016$PartyID, labels=c("KMT","DPP","NP","PFP", "TSU", "NPP","NA"))
> # Check the variable
> attach(TEDS_2016)
> head(PartyID)
[1] NA  NA  KMT NA  NA  DPP
Levels: KMT DPP NP PFP TSU NPP NA
> 

then I received very NA in the first column.
Question 5:
Answer: then when I installed the ## install.packages("descr"), and run the library I cuold see all data without NA.

TEDS_2016$PartyID 
      Frequency  Percent
KMT         388  22.9586
DPP         591  34.9704
NP            3   0.1775
PFP          32   1.8935
TSU           5   0.2959
NPP          43   2.5444
NA          628  37.1598
Total      1690 100.0000
> 


Questuin 8
> TEDS_2016$Tondu<-as.numeric(TEDS_2016$Tondu,labels=c("Unification now”,
+ “Status quo, unif. in future”, “Status quo, decide later", "Status quo
+ forever", "Status quo, indep. in future", "Independence now”, “No response"))
> library(haven)
> > TEDS_2016$Tondu<-as.numeric(TEDS_2016$Tondu,labels=c("Unification now”,
Error: unexpected '>' in ">"
> + “Status quo, unif. in future”, “Status quo, decide later", "Status quo
Error: unexpected input in "+ “"
> + forever", "Status quo, indep. in future", "Independence now”, “No response"))
Error: unexpected string constant in "+ forever", ""
> TEDS_2016$Tondu<-as.numeric(TEDS_2016$Tondu,labels=c("Unification now”,
+ “Status quo, unif. in future”, “Status quo, decide later", "Status quo
+ forever", "Status quo, indep. in future", "Independence now”, “No response"))
> TEDS_2016$Tondu<-as.numeric(TEDS_2016$Tondu,labels=c("Unification now”,
+ “Status quo, unif. in future”, “Status quo, decide later", "Status quo
+ forever", "Status quo, indep. in future", "Independence now”, “No response"))
> TEDS_2016$Tondu<-as.numeric(TEDS_2016$Tondu,labels=c("Unification now”, “Status quo, unif. in future”, “Status quo, decide later", "Status quo forever", "Status quo, indep. in future", "Independence now”, “No response"))
> attach(TEDS_2016)
The following objects are masked from TEDS_2016 (pos = 14):

    age, Age, Arear, Blue, Career, Career8, District, DPP, Econ_worse, econworse5, edu, Edu, Ethnic,
    female, Govt_dont_care, Govt_for_public, green, Green, highincome, income, income_nm,
    Independence, Inequality, inequality5, KMT, lowincome, Mainland_father, Minnan_father, nI2,
    No_Party, noparty, north, npp, Party, PartyID, pfp, pubwelf5, Sex, South, sq, Taiwanese, Tondu,
    Tondu3, Unification, voteblue, voteblue_nm, votedpp_1, votekmt, votekmt_1, votekmt_nm, votetsai,
    votetsai_all, votetsai_nm, whitecollar

> head(Tondu)
[1] 3 5 3 5 9 4
> tail(Tondu)
[1] 2 3 4 4 3 3
> library (descr)
> freq(EDS_2016$Tondu)
Error: object 'EDS_2016' not found
>  freq(TEDS_2016$Tondu)
TEDS_2016$Tondu 
      Frequency Percent
1            27   1.598
2           180  10.651
3           546  32.308
4           328  19.408
5           380  22.485
6           108   6.391
9           121   7.160
Total      1690 100.000
>
> ggplot(TEDS_2016,aes(Tondu))+ geom_bar()
> save.image("C:\\Users\\smvic\\Documents\\Knowledge Mining\\second session assignment\\.RData")
> 

I had a challenge when I wanted to make this code 
> ggplot(TEDS_2016, aes(x = Tondu)) +
+   geom_bar(aes(y = (..count..)/sum(..count..))) +
+   scale_y_continuous(labels = percent) +
+   xlab("Taiwan–China Status Preference") +
+   ylab("Percentage of Respondents (%)")

I did not know that what would be the x lable and y lable for this report
